page.title: Basic, Single-Clause Sentences - Pro-Drop
page.introduction: Some languages are pro-drop languages which allow a subject and/or object to be missing. This is not allowed in English (except for imperatives). Here is an example from Spanish which means "I buy a book":

form.prompt: Key any examples of pro-drop from your language here:

radioGroup.prompt: Does your language allow pro-drop of the subject?
radioGroup.radio: No, the subject must be overt in all cases
No, the subject must be overt except in imperatives
Yes, pro-drop of the subject is allowed

form.instruction: In the lexicon, mark any affixes that indicate imperative and any inherently imperative verbs with the feature imperative.

radioGroup.prompt: Does your language allow pro-drop of the subject?
radioGroup.radio: Not really, but pronominal clitics sometimes attach to the verb and no separate word or phrase is in subject position.
No, the subject must be a separate, overt word or phrase in all cases
No, the subject must be a separate, overt word or phrase except in imperatives
Yes, pro-drop of the subject is allowed

form.instruction:
In this case, you have two choices:
If only a few of the pronouns may/must attach as clitics, you can write a CC table pre-pass that will split the clitic into a separate word. Then add a root entry to your lexicon for that clitic with the category Pron and correct agreement features. If you implement this option, then choose the appropriate no answer above.
If you have a number of pronouns that may/must attach as clitics or you do not want to write a CC-table pre-pass, then choose the yes answer above.
In the lexicon, mark any affixes that indicate imperative and any inherently imperative verbs with the feature imperative.
